Last night in class, we discussed the assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place  Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores the concepts of "implacement" and "displacement." Casey makes a compelling argument that our contemporary world and culture are centered around time as the situating force  we're constantly racing against time, we've saved time, and we're just in time. He posits that using place as the foundation of culture fosters a more grounded community.

I put down my book and went to open the door, only to find no one there. Returning to my studies, I was about to resume my efforts when the doorbell rang again. Once more, no one was at the door, leaving me to wonder what a struggling math student needs â€“ an uninvited practical joker.

Magic fans beware... Wizards is hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, the gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game-winning bombs. Wizards of the coast seem to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can earn gold, and gold is crucial. Gold is so important that they've implemented a daily cap, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in the game. But get ready for a long and tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly four hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.

I'll tackle the unpleasant aspects first in the third installment of the trilogy. I strongly dislike pre-quals, as it's a step backward in storytelling, rather than moving the narrative forward. While it does provide more story context, the combat feels sloppy and lacks the sharpness Arkham City achieved in its combat mechanics. As of the time of writing this review (October 26, 2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from being completed (the main story is not affected). Some gadgets are placed at an inconvenient hotkey that requires you to traverse the entire keyboard to access it, which might seem minor, but could potentially disrupt your combo in combat.

They basically fixed Shadow Warrior 2013, i.e., the boss fights are awesome, weapons feel very nice, maybe not as good as D44m's ones, but still solid, enemies aren't too spongy if you're not too much of a retard with handling elemental and upgrade stuff. The upgrade system is really balanced and once you get around it, it's not too tedious. The elemental stuff and limited ammo softly forces you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique weapons that stay viable through most of the game.

So many things went wrong. I'm struggling to start this review. This all relates to my career. My player is an outside scorer, 1.71m, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Okay, and now tell me, why the shooting skill depends on a person's height? Why can a person who has 1.74m not become as good in shooting as a person with 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in RL, made my first player with this height and noticed then I can't reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That's a clear discrimination! And why the game doesn't inform me of this before I create a character, and not even then when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

I think this Assassin's Creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, etc.). I felt much more attached to this character as well. The story starts out extremely rough but does get much better as you play. Edward was quite the interesting character and so were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually meant something in this AC game that I never got from any of the previous ones, and maybe it's because I felt like they had a bigger purpose in the game. They definitely were not required but they were fun to get and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game  it's pay-to-win. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and hardsuit is an excellent idea. I'd take this game over any call of duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20 hours. I would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. The aiming reticule is on the small side, and zoom is underpowered. With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first-person shooter/beat 'em up is great. I've been playing it as often as I can get away, just one more mission, just one more supply run, or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

An absolute great strategy game! Having played every single other war game (European Escalation and Alpha), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is great. The graphics are just beautiful, the sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining, I am not kidding. However, if you think this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Don't get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.

I was initially skeptical about this game before playing it. I wasn't even sure about buying it. The portal gun and portal concept seemed unusual to me, even though I enjoy science fiction. I was wrong. The humor and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. They're not cheesy (okay, they're occasionally cheesy). The different story characters all have their own sense of humor. Those distinct characters genuinely have different personalities. And the level design is just fantastic. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have played it if I hadn't played the sequel.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember watching the ever-irritating Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is present. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. The combat mechanics are extremely well-done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, seamlessly integrated into combos, making it unlike other high-profile games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a bit, but it was unremarkable. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing the game. There's a frustrating bug where it insists on updating the terms of service, only to prompt me to restart the client when I click "accept." I'm not thrilled about linking my Steam and Gface accounts, as it seems unnecessary for DLC and non-reversible, allowing a company I don't care about to access my Steam information. The game itself is unimpressive, easily recognizable as a Call of Duty clone, and somehow they managed to make the gunplay worse.

I experienced no performance problems even at release, and after all these patches, it plays really well. In my opinion, this is a really great and fun game, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play Batman + one more, and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game, but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the APC commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the brakes to skid around corners, and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable.

Here's the bottom line  the game is great, but it's not without its flaws. It has great FPS, nice story, cool characters, and a great soundtrack, but some cutscenes can be quite cruel and vivid. If you're not prepared, it's not for the faint of heart. However, when a game is this good, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are  no SLI support, which was a problem for me since I had to put the game away until I upgraded my card. Make sure you have a decent single GPU card.

The game's graphics are set in a comic-like style, with very slick and detailed visuals. The color scheme is nice and works well for this game. The graphics can be set on 'high' without straining your system. I played this game on an i5 processor with an Nvidia GeForce 710M card and 8GB of RAM, running Windows 8.1, and it ran smoothly. The controls are versatile, allowing players to play with a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller.

You can see the hours I've invested in this game, and I must say, I thoroughly enjoy it. This is everything I wished for in a search game from Cod would be. However, don't buy this game thinking it's like Cod, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's a game in its own class and should be treated as such. I've heard numerous times new players complain about getting killed really fast. Oh, the horror! It's not like that doesn't happen in real life or anything. I've been playing this game for a while now, throwing all kinds of money at it. It's one of the best multiplayer games around. A good thing to play when you're not feeling CS GO.

I'm 2 hours in and I'm dying from laughter from this game. So funny. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, the story/world has me hooked, and the puzzles are fun. But the best part about this game is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you've never played an RPG before, you should still enjoy the game for its humor.

I'm really sorry to say that I didn't enjoy this game, despite its promising description. As a fan of free-to-play games and indie developers, I was excited to try this game, but unfortunately, the execution fell short of my expectations. As someone who loves puzzle and exploration games, I found this game to be frustratingly unintuitive, and even after seeking guidance, I struggled to find the gameplay enjoyable. The lack of a pause button is also a significant oversight, especially given the timed sequences in the game. It feels like the game is more cutscene than gameplay, leaving me feeling bored and impatient.

This game was an absolute delight from start to finish. I was hooked from the story to the graphics. The story wasn't just a narrative, it felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the story my character was telling. Gameplay was excellent and I learned a lot about myself through this game, mainly my fear of heights, which I never had an issue with until the ice caverns. My stomach churned the whole time, but I persisted for Uncle Fred!

Sid Meier's Civilization  Beyond Earth is a turn-based game in which you build your civilization to a certain goal or 'victory'. In this game, you are set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. I enjoy the game's new approach and added mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer. However, I didn't enjoy that the game could be overwhelming at times. To improve this game, incorporating new artwork, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader, could be a great addition.

Great game! Tons of replayability and very fun zombie survival game! In my top 5 zombie games ever played. After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror, as you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. I find zombies to feel very natural to be well animated for a free-to-play game. I would recommend getting one or two friends to play with, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends/talk with the people in the chat or over voice comms.

It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game, as from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two game breakers. No Aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, and creates unbearable lag. Mind you, I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the game. Everything's artifacts like crazy - the menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card, and thought it might not like my OC.

I finished the game last night, and while the story isn't particularly deep or captivating, the storytelling is what makes it stand out. The atmosphere is richly detailed, and the many collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I learned a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a slight letdown that there were so few boss battles. However, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge, but it's on the easier side. Leveling up Batman wasn't particularly satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Getting access to previously unreachable places makes for a sense of progression.

"To the moon is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Telltale's the walking dead is sad? Ah, it's no match for a trip to the moon! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor is great and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the references are endless.

Bastion is a brilliant game with a captivating storyline. After a calamity, you start to rebuild on the bastion. The game offers a wide range of choices, allowing you to decide what to build for an advantage, what weapons to wield, and what power-ups to have on those weapons, as well as what drinks to consume for a bonus effect. The art style and music are fantastic, making the game visually stunning and engaging. Additionally, the game features narration that adapts to the player's actions, so if you pick up a weapon and switch it for another in the armory, the narration will reflect your new selection.

I acquired this game during its early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no tech tree. This was when the game was at its best. All the guns at this stage were equally overpowered, so there were no balance issues; anyone could kill anyone at any time. Additionally, the game used to provide unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You might think that for a game with 'billions of guns', they would at least offer more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before you had to pay to access more. At one point, I had about 3 pages worth of guns and was planning on new ideas for more, as personally, that's where I found it most enjoyable.

This game was a surprising gem, with rave reviews often reflecting the fun of this neat little game. It's an odd mix between a classic 2D platformer and an MOBA, done with style. I found myself enjoying characters I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a go anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games.

I just started playing, but I'm thoroughly enthralled by this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. The music perfectly sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are superb. I eagerly anticipate each combat, and they've executed combat extremely well. I had some reservations about the naval combat system, but it's so much fun to unleash havoc on multiple fleets at once! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat appears overwhelming, simply regroup and counter-assault. Thank you, developers, for an incredible experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it's certainly for the better; and this new game by Ninja Theory proves it. DMC serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch.

Where do I start on this enchanting game? It's story is absolutely charming. It has so much detail invested in it, and it's a bundle of happiness, bad puns, and secrets. The character design is on point, with various characters having distinct personalities and secrets to them. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an innovative concept in RPGs. With lots of inspiration from Earthbound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, you can tell it's going to be great. It easily has the best soundtrack I've heard in a while.

I recommend this experience solely because it's free and may be a more enjoyable experience for others. For my part, the game didn't resonate with me. Half the story relies on shock value, but I wasn't shocked or emotionally moved in any way. Perhaps I'm desensitized or maybe it was too simplistic to elicit a reaction from me. The other half of the game attempts to paint a picture of a person's mental decline. It explores obsession, hallucinations, depression, and a few other themes. In theory, it's an innovative concept. However, the game took me 10 minutes to complete, and that's including reading and absorbing every detail.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally only had two  one minor and the other quite annoying), I can definitely recommend this space exploration game. I'll include my specs  i5 6600k, Radeon RX 480, Z170 Pro Gaming, 16GB DDR4 RAM, and a total of ~650â‚¬, which is within the medium price range. Although this rig is quite new, I can genuinely confirm that I'm getting almost constant 80+ FPS on high settings with vsync enabled.

Remember, the age of mythology? Yeah, it's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity  Dragon Commander reaches awfully close to these borders of my personal most favourite RTS game. Combine this with a huge risk-like grand strategy mode, and there, it hits the spot. I am not (read  try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking and even commanding unit production, direction and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, I do like the complicated RTS games nowadays. Think of Civ V and so on.

The game Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is nice, but paired together they make some truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script runs the gamut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning RPG tropes on their head. It's a game that turns RPG cliches on their head, but in a way that feels fresh and original.

I've had this game for just a few months, and in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already excellent game into an even better one. The developers are highly active in the community, evident in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I'm still trying to master; however, this breadth of strategy allows for a myriad of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. I find myself engrossed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those hours, you'll begin to see that the game offers little beyond its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The developers are working hard, making semi-regular updates with significant changes to the game's systems, new Warframes, and features. It's a good game to play casually.

This game is so unimpressive. Very. Boring. I purchased this game thinking it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and nice PS2 game. Unfortunately, it's far from it. In this game, you absorb ever-larger objects to grow bigger and absorb even larger objects. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be; the levels are not inventive and what's in it is a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show, but one that makes you question whether being alive is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.

I was very interested in this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" However, it wasn't as enjoyable as I had hoped. The game starts by asking you to choose a side  Republican or Democrat, with no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed, I was still optimistic and decided to see what I could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to play around with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign, literally.

Fallout 3's story was marred by the presence of settlements, which can hinder your progress and make you wish you were playing the story instead of managing them. Some keys are hard-coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs abound. My Pip-Boy disappeared permanently at one point, and I had to research console commands to get it back. Power armor is readily available, as it's basically given to you from the beginning of the game, and power cores are abundant in trader shops. The value of power armor has diminished greatly from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, with everything about this game being average except for its stability. It doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3, making it a more stable experience. However, it's not better than Fallout 3, and it's not better than New Vegas. This title was overhyped for how mediocre it actually is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review)  8.6 hours to get to the end, 10 collectibles found out of 25, zero achievements out of 15. What I liked  visuals up until the last level (Ice Caves), story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) kind of made me not regret so much spending my time playing this game. What I disliked  visuals in the last level are uninteresting, gameplay in the last level gets much harder, making it become a frustrating experience of having to do a lot of things over and over again until you get it right, achievements are too hard.

Pros  +graphic cons  -bugs (especially the environment, where you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight of the enemy) -game is handholding/babysitting you -dumb AI -enemies always seem to know where you are when you're spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy, which is frustrating, like the first Ghost Warrior. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that I couldn't care less about; I won't recommend it unless it's 90% off, even then I find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move onto the next game in my library.

Do not buy this game, servers offline. You can't play. No comprare this game, servers offline. No puedes jugar. I enjoyed it. The song of the Steve Miller Band is catchy. Go on, take the money and run! Some guns are overpowered and matchmaking can be unfair. However, 73 minutes of playing the game is an hour well spent. It's awesome!

It's not difficult for me to understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a vivid imagination and I'm more interested in playing room-sized games with controllers. Beyond that, the game's initial awe-inspiring universe scale was a hindrance to my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and the time required to do anything engaging at the beginning were both overwhelming for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be more compelling.

My favorite first-person shooter of all time is a hands-down favorite. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply; recoil and ballistics are realistic. A single hit to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always results in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required to remain on target. There's no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine, you'll have a pouch full of half-full mags. You can't run forever; if you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you've caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me begin by stating I didn't purchase EU when it first launched, and I got it on sale, which included EU, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game, however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM2, I love it; the game plays well for me on medium settings, and I'm running a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. When I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what, but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they're coming from some really entitled people.

This game offers a wide variety of ship types with physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles, making it easy to learn and manage resources. It has a dark humor and can be a grind, but it's still fun. Despite some drawbacks, there's still some variety and strategy to be had. The game starts off fast and picks up quickly. Although there's a limited variety of equipment and leveling skills, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is through mods. The fight for universe is easily the star, but the big fight for beef is also very good.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty, more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. The UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEForum are expected to be muted. Anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEForum's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline Looms for Fiat-GM Deal: Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to resolve their disagreement over a potential takeover. This marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, as part of an alliance agreed upon in 2000. GM, whose European operations are currently losing money, no longer wishes to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of stalled talks caused Fiat's shares to decline 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% gain on Monday due to hopes of a settlement. GM is reportedly offering approximately $2 billion (Â£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement. The US firm has argued that the deal is void due to Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to form an alliance with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, the head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has criticized the Iraq war, saying it was a "terrible" waste of billions of pounds. He made the comments on BBC Radio 4, reiterating his stance in his Christmas Midnight Mass.

Debra Hill, a renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 1978 horror classic Halloween, has passed away at the age of 54 in Los Angeles. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film achieved a record-breaking $60 million worldwide, a feat for an independent film at that time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. As a pioneering woman in film, Hill was recognized for taking on roles in the 1970s that were typically reserved for men.

Broadband fuels online expression and fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. According to a report by UK think-tank demos, a quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal sites. Having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is growing fast. The report found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. Significantly, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos, the Russian oil and gas company, is due in a US court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities to pay a $27bn (Â£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site, where voting is currently underway for the annual Bloggies, recognizing the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, and traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to an overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog.

Chinese dam firm defies Beijing's order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the Chinese state press has said. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, according to the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to halt due to a lack of proper environmental checks. The Beijing News stated that the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Ferguson has hailed Manchester United's resolve in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," he said. "We showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.

The film about singer George Michael's life will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. The documentary, which runs from February 10-20, features George Michael discussing his career and personal life, from his early days in Wham! to more recent events. George Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also attend the festival. The 93-minute film will see George Michael discussing his early days in Wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

The US singles chart now incorporates digital music downloads for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now combines data from sales of music downloads and physical singles. Green Day's Boulevard of Broken Dreams currently ranks number two on Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. The incorporation of download sales into the UK singles chart is scheduled for later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart.

The self-proclaimed spam king, Scott Richter, is seeking bankruptcy protection for his company, Optinrealbig.com, which has been hit with lawsuits. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, including a notable one against Microsoft, which is seeking millions in damages. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to resolve its legal issues and continue trading. As the third-largest spammer in the world, according to junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, Optinrealbig was sued in December 2003 for sending millions of spam messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Richter and his co-conspirators sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini, Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini had felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems." Arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added  "Santini has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it."

Economy will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown said, as the party gears up for the election battle. Brown, speaking after the Cabinet's last meeting at 10 Downing Street before the expected election announcement, said voters would recognize that Labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. The Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the Lib Dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax.

Brizzel to run at the AAA's in Sheffield, Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not run in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will hope to confirm his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed in mid-week that he would join Cragg in the European championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment, with Cragg occupying top spot.

Robinson, a former rugby league international, has targeted dual code success against Australia on Saturday. As a former rugby league captain, Jason Robinson has led England against Australia at Twickenham at 14 30 GMT. The team will look to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as gain revenge for June's 51-15 hammering by the Wallabies.

Warning  A tsunami aid website is claiming to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible because it uses an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, it has no connection to the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. This is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterizes many other phishing attempts.

Iraq is inviting phone licence bids to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade, saying it wants to increase its "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years.

More women are taking charge of protecting their home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect their PCs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women were buying security software than retired men.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio, an Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a significant amount of space to fill. However, more and more iPod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an eclectic assortment of producers. This phenomenon is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, although you do not need an iPod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show, which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own homes. They require only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.

Levy wins Whitbread novel prize, Andrea Levy's novel, Orange Prize winner, and she's now favourite to win overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughren picked up children's fiction award for third time for 'Not the End of the World'. All category winners go through to compete for Whitbread Book of the Year title, which carries Â£25,000 prize.

Yukos seeks court action on sale, Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yukos for $20bn in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear.

Hearts defeated Livingston 2-1 in their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie, scoring two goals in the opening 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself scored the second when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held on.

Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users 53 dollars for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz.

Jamieson issues a warning to bigots in Scotland's justice minister that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their work in tackling the problem. The minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective.

Kevin Spacey, Kate Bosworth, and other Hollywood stars attended the British premiere of the new film, "Beyond the Sea", in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife - real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v saracens (fri) headingley friday, 25 february 2000 gmt the tykes have brought in newcastle prop ed kalman and tom mcgee from the borders on loan while fly-half craig mcmullen has joined from narbonne. Raphael ibanez is named at hooker for saracens in one of four changes. Simon raiwalui and ben russell are selected in the pack while kevin sorrell comes in at outside centre.

Home phones face unclear future the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the UK, Germany, and South Korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile.

Melzer Shocks Agassi in Quarter-Finals of SAP Open

Second-seeded Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat at the hands of Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. The Austrian's clever drop shots often left Agassi bamboozled, resulting in a 6-3, 6-1 loss. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to beat Thomas Enqvist of Sweden 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Meanwhile, unseeded Cyril Saulnier upset fourth-seeded Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth-seeded Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," Melzer said. "It's always challenging to face Andre, as he makes you run extensively across the court."

The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the lords.

Disappointed Scott Allan is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the JosÃ© M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete.

A US woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), claiming its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia says a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer it needs re-filling, even when it doesn't. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. The suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty.

Roxy Music will appear at the Isle of Wight Music Festival, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The band has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzurana, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other hits including "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy."

Captains lining up for aid match Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a Tsumani fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer.

Spirit Awards hail the comedy Sideways, which has dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars.

Prince crowned 'top music earner' prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artists such as Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5 million (Â£30.4 million) from concerts, album, and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9 million (Â£29.5 million) while embarking on her global re-invention tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9 million (Â£13.4 million) last year. "Prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported.

Blue beat U2 to the top of France honour Irish band U2 have been honoured at France's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by boy band Blue. U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ music awards, but Blue beat them to the international group award. The band Maroon 5 was named best new international artist, and took the best international song title for this love. More than five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French  "I'm not from this country but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the CÃ´te d'Azur I feel at home."

The proposed plan would require local communities to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. According to party leader Michael Howard, the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He emphasized that the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats, however, raised concerns that the plan could allow extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Conservative promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, stressed the importance of retaining operational independence. Jan Berry, the chairman, warned that the plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what happens on the ground, stating, "it is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches."

At a glance  Tory health checks for UK's opposition conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. The plan is aimed at people coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of TB, they would have to have a chest X-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the European Union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical check, including tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case-by-case basis.

Doves soar to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, ousting flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters from the number one spot. The trio's album follows the success of their single "Black and White Town", which reached number six. Meanwhile, R&B star Nelly claims the new number one single with "Over and Over", a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Other notable entries in the top ten include Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs, as well as Futureheads and Usher. Elvis Presley's latest re-release, "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame", debuts at number three, just one place ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up". Hip-hop performer Akon's "Locked Up" takes the fifth spot, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs score their second chart hit with "Oh My God".

Davies prefers Gloucester's future over Wales' hooker offer. Mefin Davies, a 32-year-old hooker, is likely to remain with English club Gloucester despite reported interest from the Ospreys. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys are interested in Davies, but he would prefer to stay at Gloucester. Davies, a standout performer in Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is currently on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. Having proven his worth to the Zurich Premiership side, he is expected to receive a new deal next season. The collapse of the Celtic Warriors region in the summer left Davies without a professional contract, prompting him to sign a semi-professional deal with Neath RFC. Although he received match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, Davies admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was upset about his treatment.

Cabinet anger at Brown's cash raid, ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall's cash to keep council tax bills down. Local government minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated Â£512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr. Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a Â£1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is set to make history by fielding four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, in the UEFA Cup. The Arab club, based in Sakhnin, near Haifa, will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who impressed at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a key role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. The 25-year-old goalkeeper recently joined the club after a brief stint with South African side Hellenic. Last season, Bnei Sakhnin won the Israeli Cup final and are known for their strong ethic and high-profile promotion of peace and cooperation within Israel.

New research suggests that reducing the drink-drive limit could save more lives than previously thought. According to a report, cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The study, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, claims that this change would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003. The research is being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs are set to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1x1 Î¼mÂ² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle within the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512x512 Î¼mÂ². Unlike conventional systems, this design measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline, eliminating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

The routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVS) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVS.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the creation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. This capability has encouraged ideas for using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. The linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. However, optomechanical proposals have noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers who have learned increasingly sophisticated and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are difficult to capture as they can evolve quickly over time, differ across spammers, and remain unknown in most cases. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game where spammers and detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy.

We developed single-shot, shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (UH-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in a lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (LR) method to derive a family of solutions, leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the LR invariant. We identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an UH-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above 10^-4. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to non-convexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same structure that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over-or under-specified.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by some suitable subgroup g of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface x_m in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial w_m. The first, Berglund-HÃ¼bsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface x_m^t inside it by some dual group g^t. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of the study on human gait was made by combining existing models from the literature, such as Keller and Kockshenev's models. In this hybrid model, a metabolic energy minimization strategy is combined with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data for different speed regimes indicate that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a relevant quantity in quantifying this dynamic process.

We present a novel mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method is based on a time regularization technique that maintains the stability properties of the symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during close encounters. We employ a high-order MVS scheme, enabling integration with large time steps far from close encounters. We demonstrate that this algorithm can resolve almost exact collisions, with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius, using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problems such as the solar system. Our long-term behavior is shown on systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering for 50,000 years. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as Mercury and find that for an equivalent cost, we achieve much better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. Due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size, it is challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For n-partite GHZ-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires n+1 local measurement settings and can tolerate up to 1/2 white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure depending only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. This can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, providing a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Our results demonstrate that current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates place only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case where edges can be short-term interactions or long-term structural connections. In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both expensive to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. We develop and validate models for transducing beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. This research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs. Our goal is to achieve strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the GMS of the PCW, enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting comes from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences separate into short exact sequences.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as Euclid or LSST. In this first paper of a series of two, we use simulations to build a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). We develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard LCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, have been shown to be amongst the most challenging audio files to process. Building speech processing models capable of handling such a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies, where researchers are interested in the quality of the speech children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. We present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech.

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, unknown, population structure allows framing the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, draws a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, governing the shape of the density and hence possibly the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher-dimensional operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles resurrects the interference, recouping sensitivity to the non-interfering operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is the goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often frowned upon data analyses with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" provides a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in such a way that it naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. We organize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks  description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). An explicit classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task.

The weak gravity conjecture demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore suggests that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is unclear what is wrong if this doesn't occur. This note shows that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, the stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a non-perturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity vc. We measure vc as a function of interaction strength, finding a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids, providing new insights into the long-standing problem of unconventional superconductivity.

Ordinary differential equations (ODE) are a mathematical model used in many application areas such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, with their intuitive appeal to modeling. Despite ODE's wide usage in modeling, frequent absence of their analytic solutions makes it difficult to estimate ODE parameters from the data, especially when the model has many variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimating algorithm, which is fast and accurate even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on equations of a numeric solver. It allows for fast estimation by avoiding computations of a whole numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained by a variational Bayesian method, specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method.

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nSN junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs that are generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. The long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity is a concern, especially if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Our examination of the long-term behavior of titanium-implanted alumina reveals that after an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity shows a very slow decrease of approximately 10% over the following year.

We introduce a novel, Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, rooted in the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the Skyrme charge for any smooth configuration. Notably, singular configurations can be identified as n_f=1 baryons, charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, vector mesons assume the role of Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet forming the n_f=1 baryon. We propose this current as the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies, yielding a unified framework for both types of baryons and enabling a natural transformation between them. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers an intriguing means to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We theoretically investigate how the superposition of both effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially established for usual tunneling Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. A clear spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jimenez (2020), it is found that dipoles are as important to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores. The kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small fast-moving cores, and another family of larger slowly moving ones, which can be described as "frozen" into a slowly evolving "crystal."

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely valuable framework for the design of several quantum algorithms. The running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time  the time required by the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor  from o(n^5) to o(n^2logn).

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered as the main EMRI sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. We highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel  wet EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). This channel captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about him/her, i.e. No interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems to attract the users at the first time so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into the new user cold-start category, which is crucial to the development and even survival of a company.

Deep learning has successfully solved many problems that are out of reach for heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been obtained by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. This, however, often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To this end, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the whole receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5g-compliant fashion. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds will often contain thousands of similar inputs. This lack of diversity can lead to wasted fuzzing effort by exhaustive mutation from all available seeds.
